pr_title: Added to primitive iterables toArray() method which takes an array parameter

timeline.message:
Added to primitive iteralbles toArray() method which takes an array as a parameter to store the elements of the iterable

Signed-off-by: vmzakharov <zakharov.vladimir.m@gmail.com>

timeline.bodyText: If you implement this as a default method, then we can release in a minor version.
timeline.author: donraab
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -63,6 +63,13 @@ public interface <name>Iterable extends PrimitiveIterable
      */
     <type>[] toArray();
 
+    /**
+     * Converts the <name>Iterable to a primitive <type> array. If the collection fits into the provided array it is used
+     * to store its elements and is returned from the method, otherwise a new array of the appropriate size is allocated
+     * and returned. If the iterable is empty, the target array is returned unchanged.
+     */
+    <type>[] toArray(<type>[] target);

timeline.bodyText: Nitpick: I don't see much advantage of using forEachWithOccurrences when the output is of size size(). Might as well delegate to forEachWithIndex or forEach?
timeline.author: motlin

timeline.bodyText: Is this an unrelated change that snuck in?
timeline.author: motlin

replies.bodyText: It's actually the reason for the change I believe. I was going to comment but then thought this is probably a good use case validation that the behavior is working. I believe this was the only use case I saw other than tests.
replies.author: donraab

replies.bodyText: This could be clarified in the commit message or be a separate commit to split the use case from the change.
replies.author: donraab

replies.bodyText: @motlin - a related change that snuck in. I will take it out from this PR.  @donraab is correct, there will be a separate change to take advantage of the toArray(target) in factory methods.
replies.author: vmzakharov
